frameDefinitions: Two (or more) people (the Interlocutors, also encodable as Interlocutor_1 and Interlocutor_2) talk to one another.
A Cognizer makes a judgment about an Evaluee.
The words in this frame have to do with non-verbal communication.
Item-1 and Item-2 are compatible with each other if they can exist or function together in some context without problems, conflict, or other undesirable situation.
A particular piece of Information is evaluated for its accuracy.
The Cognizers have a similarity (or dissimilarity) in their Opinion.
frameExamples: I would rather <t>discuss</t> politics with anyone but him.
JUDGMENT:  She <t>admired</t> Einstein for his character.
I <t>gestured</t> with my hand for him to come over.
Make sure your site is <t>compatible</t> with any browser.
Is your reputation at risk due to <t>incorrect</t> information?
Dr. Gerry and Mr. Pond <t>agree</t> in their impressions.
listRoleDefinitions: In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as compared with <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen> is generally encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>.  Thus a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that of <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Interlocutors</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> refers to the semantically and grammatically less prominent group.  It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by <ment>with</ment>).  Note that it is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents. For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Interlocutors</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Interlocutors</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Discussion frame, it is possible for the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.

<fen>Topic</fen> expresses the subject that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> are trying to come to some agreement about.  It may refer, for example, to an undesirable issue that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> want to have the proper response to, or it may refer more directly to an unresolved question.
The time at which the discussion takes place.
The location at which a discussion takes place.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the judgment. This role is typically expressed as the External Argument (or in a <ment>by</ment>-PP in passives).
Evaluee is the person or thing about whom/which a judgment is made. With verbs this role is typically expressed as Object:
Typically, there is a constituent expressing the <t>Reason</t> for the Judge's judgment. It is usually a <ment>for</ment>-PP, e.g.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the judgment made by the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
This is the sentient entity that communicates a Message non-verbally. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Communicator'>The teacher</fex> <t>gestured</t> us into the room.

This is the person to whom a non-verbal Message is communicated. It may be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>us</fex> into the room. The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to us</fex> to enter the room.

This is the content of non-verbal communication. It may be expressed as a <ment>that</ment>-clause Complement, a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP Complement, or a directional PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Message'>that it was time to leave</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> to us <fex name='Message'>to enter the room</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> us <fex name='Message'>into the room</fex>.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific body part of the <fen>Communicator</fen> which gestures.
The <fen>Indicated_entity</fen> is the entity which the <fen>Communicator</fen> is pointing out to the <fen>Addressee</fen> as meaningful.
When the gesturing occus.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the gesturing occurs.
The Frame Element <fen>Item_1</fen> marks the grammatically more prominent of the two entities, i.e.the subject in active clauses, when they are expressed separately.
The Frame Element <fen>Item_2</fen> marks the grammatically less prominent of the <fen>Items</fen> when they are expressed separately.
This role is used when the <fen>Items</fen> are expressed jointly in a phrase, either a plural or a coordinated NP.
This Frame Element is used for expressions that indicate a <fen>Parameter</fen> or respect in which the <fen>Items</fen> are said to be compatible, not in conflict.
The <fen>Information</fen> matches or does not match the facts of the world.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the agent who holds the correct/incorrect information.
The event which communicates the <fen>Information</fen>.
The Topic about which the Source has accurate information.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Information</fen> or the <fen>Source</fen> is correct.
This role marks constituents that express the set of <fen>Cognizers</fen> whose similarity of opinion is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Cognizer_1</fen> is the individual characterized by their similarity in opinion to <fen>Cognizer_2</fen>, whose opinion is assumed to be known.  <fen>Cognizer_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Cognizer_2</fen> is the one whose opinion is assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing the opinion of <fen>Cognizer_1</fen>.

This role denotes an implicit question in response to which the <fen>Cognizers</fen> give their <fen>Opinion</fen>s, which are then assessed for their similarity.  The <fen>Question</fen> may concern the identitiy of a particular entity, as in the first example below, or it may be of the yes/no-type, as in the second example below.
A state of affairs believed by the <fen>Cognizers</fen>.
A phenomenon that the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are considering with respect to their <fen>Opinion</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are in agreement or disagreement.
The Place is the general area in which the Cognizers are in agreement or disagreement.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The President</fex> conferred with his top advisor.
The President debated <fex>with his top advisor</fex>.
(1) <fex>The President and his advisor</fex> discussed the Venezuelan situation briefly before the summit.
The President and his top advisors discussed <fex>the scandal</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex> the participants discussed taking down the last trade barriers without consensus.
We just conferred for a couple of hours <fex>up in her room</fex>.
<fex>The boss</fex> appreciates you for your diligence.
The boss appreciates <fex>you</fex> for your diligence.
She viewed him with an appreciative <fex>gaze</fex>.
<fex>That technology</fex> turned out not to be compatible with the existing devices
My computer is not compatible <fex>with my new printer</fex>.
The two applications are compatible <fex>in their essential features</fex>.
I think we see eye to eye <fex>in our ultimate goal</fex>, which is that we want to see a democratic Serbia.
We agree <fex>that babies should not be dropped from helicopters</fex>.
